member.name: M:UsefulThings.Extensions.ReadStreamFully(System.IO.Stream,System.Int32)
member.summary:
KFreon: Borrowed this from the DevIL C# Wrapper found here: https://code.google.com/p/devil-net/
Reads a stream until the end is reached into a byte array. Based on Jon Skeet's implementation. It is up to the caller to dispose of the stream.
member.param: Stream to read all bytes from
member.returns: The byte array containing all the bytes from the stream

member.name: T:UsefulThings.MemoryTributary
member.summary: MemoryTributary is a re-implementation of MemoryTributary that uses a dynamic list of byte arrays as a backing store, instead of a single byte array, the allocation of which will fail for relatively small streams as it requires contiguous memory.

member.name: M:UsefulThings.MemoryTributary.#ctor
member.summary: Creates an empty MemoryTributary-like instance which doesn't require contiguous memory.

member.name: M:UsefulThings.MemoryTributary.#ctor(System.Byte[])
member.summary: Creates a MemoryTributary-like instance which doesn't require contiguous memory, based on a byte[] source.

member.name: M:UsefulThings.MemoryTributary.#ctor(System.Int32)
member.summary: Creates a MemoryTributary-like instance which doesn't require contiguous memory, with length (ignored).

member.name: P:UsefulThings.MemoryTributary.block
member.summary: The block of memory currently addressed by Position

member.name: P:UsefulThings.MemoryTributary.blockId
member.summary: The id of the block currently addressed by Position

member.name: P:UsefulThings.MemoryTributary.blockOffset
member.summary: The offset of the byte currently addressed by Position, into the block that contains it

member.name: M:UsefulThings.MemoryTributary.Flush
member.summary: Does nothing for now.

member.name: M:UsefulThings.MemoryTributary.Read(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Copies bytes from this stream at the current position TO the buffer. Doesn't reset stream position. Returns number of bytes read from stream.
member.param: Offset to begin writing at in buffer>
Number of bytes to read from stream>

member.summary: Changes stream position to given offset based on given origin. Returns new stream position.

member.name: M:UsefulThings.MemoryTributary.Write(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Writes data FROM buffer TO stream at current position. Doesn't reset stream position.
member.param: Offset to begin writing from in buffer.

member.name: M:UsefulThings.MemoryTributary.ReadByte
member.summary: Reads byte from stream at current position and advances stream.

member.name: M:UsefulThings.MemoryTributary.WriteByte(System.Byte)
member.summary: Writes byte to stream at current position and advances stream.

member.name: M:UsefulThings.MemoryTributary.ToArray
member.summary: Returns the entire content of the stream as a byte array. This is not safe because the call to new byte[] may fail if the stream is large enough. Where possible use methods which operate on streams directly instead.
member.returns: A byte[] containing the current data in the stream

member.name: M:UsefulThings.MemoryTributary.ReadFrom(System.IO.Stream,System.Int64)
member.summary: Reads length bytes from source stream into the this instance at the current position.
member.param: The stream containing the data to copy
The number of bytes to copy

member.name: M:UsefulThings.MemoryTributary.WriteTo(System.IO.Stream)
member.summary: Writes the entire stream into destination, regardless of Position, which remains unchanged.
member.param: The stream to write the content of this stream to

member.name: T:UsefulThings.WinForms.Gooey
member.summary: Allows some control over changing the state (enabled/visible) of a set of controls. Features: Exclude controls from state changes. Switch state changes between enabling and changing visibility. A function can replace state changes. e.g. Instead of enabling, set some text or whatever.

member.name: M:UsefulThings.WinForms.Gooey.ChangeState(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Changes state of all listed controls.
member.param: If true, enables/makes visible. Functions run regardless and take state as parameter.

member.name: M:UsefulThings.WinForms.Gooey.AddControl(System.Object,System.String,System.Object,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Adds given control to list of controls to be maintained by this class.
member.param: Control to be added (ToolStripItem or Form Control)
Key to identify control. MUST be a unique part of the Control name.
Effect to be run on state change. Bool or Action.
Optional. If true, this control is affected by state changes.
Optional. If true, property affected by state changes is the Enabled property, otherwise uses the visible property.

member.name: M:UsefulThings.WinForms.Gooey.ModifyControl(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Modifies control specified by key, changes whether control is affected by state changes.
member.param: If true, control is affected by state changes.

member.name: M:UsefulThings.WinForms.Gooey.GetControlAffectedState(System.String)
member.summary: Gets whether control specified by key is affected by state changes.
member.param: Key of control to look for.
member.returns: True if control is affected by state changes, else false.

member.name: T:UsefulThings.WinForms.Transitions.IManagedType
member.summary: Interface for all types we can perform transitions on. Each type (e.g. int, double, Color) that we can perform a transition on needs to have its own class that implements this interface. These classes tell the transition system how to act on objects of that type.

member.name: M:UsefulThings.WinForms.Transitions.IManagedType.getManagedType
member.summary: Returns the Type that the instance is managing.

member.name: M:UsefulThings.WinForms.Transitions.IManagedType.copy(System.Object)
member.summary: Returns a deep copy of the object passed in. (In particular this is needed for types that are objects.)

member.name: M:UsefulThings.WinForms.Transitions.IManagedType.getIntermediateValue(System.Object,System.Object,System.Double)
member.summary: Returns an object holding the value between the start and end corresponding to the percentage passed in. (Note: the percentage can be less than 0% or greater than 100%.)

member.name: M:UsefulThings.WinForms.Transitions.ITransitionType.onTimer(System.Int32,System.Double@,System.Boolean@)
member.summary:
Called by the Transition framework when its timer ticks to pass in the time (in ms) since the transition started.
You should return (in an out parameter) the percentage movement towards the destination value for the time passed in. Note: this does not need to be a smooth transition from 0% to 100%. You can overshoot with values greater than 100% or undershoot if you need to (for example, to have some form of "elasticity").
The percentage should be returned as (for example) 0.1 for 10%.
You should return (in an out parameter) whether the transition has completed. (This may not be at the same time as the percentage has moved to 100%.)

member.name: T:UsefulThings.WinForms.Transitions.ManagedType_Color
member.summary: Class that manages transitions for Color properties. For these we need to transition the R, G, B and A sub-properties independently.

member.name: M:UsefulThings.WinForms.Transitions.ManagedType_Color.getIntermediateValue(System.Object,System.Object,System.Double)
member.summary: Creates an intermediate value for the colors depending on the percentage passed in.

member.name: T:UsefulThings.WinForms.Transitions.Transition
member.summary:
Lets you perform animated transitions of properties on arbitrary objects. These will often be transitions of UI properties, for example an animated fade-in of a UI object, or an animated move of a UI object from one position to another.
Each transition can simulataneously change multiple properties, including properties across multiple objects.
Example transition ------------------ a. Transition t = new Transition(new TransitionMethod_Linear(500)); b. t.add(form1, "Width", 500); c. t.add(form1, "BackColor", Color.Red); d. t.run();
Line a: Creates a new transition. You specify the transition method.
Lines b. and c: Set the destination values of the properties you are animating.
Line d: Starts the transition.
Transition methods ------------------ TransitionMethod objects specify how the transition is made. Examples include linear transition, ease-in-ease-out and so on. Different transition methods may need different parameters.

member.name: M:UsefulThings.WinForms.Transitions.Transition.#cctor
member.summary: You should register all managed-types here.

member.name: T:UsefulThings.WinForms.Transitions.Transition.Args
member.summary: Args passed with the TransitionCompletedEvent.

member.name: E:UsefulThings.WinForms.Transitions.Transition.TransitionCompletedEvent
member.summary: Event raised when the transition hass completed.

member.name: M:UsefulThings.WinForms.Transitions.Transition.run(System.Object,System.String,System.Object,UsefulThings.WinForms.Transitions.ITransitionType)
member.summary: Creates and immediately runs a transition on the property passed in.

member.name: M:UsefulThings.WinForms.Transitions.Transition.run(System.Object,System.String,System.Object,System.Object,UsefulThings.WinForms.Transitions.ITransitionType)
member.summary: Sets the property passed in to the initial value passed in, then creates and immediately runs a transition on it.

member.name: T:UsefulThings.WinForms.Transitions.TransitionManager
member.summary: This class is responsible for running transitions. It holds the timer that triggers transaction animation.
member.remarks:
This class is a singleton.
We manage the transaction timer here so that we can have a single timer across all transactions. If each transaction has its own timer, this creates one thread for each transaction, and this can lead to too many threads in an application.
This class essentially just manages the timer for the transitions. It calls back into the running transitions, which do the actual work of the transition.

member.name: M:UsefulThings.WinForms.Transitions.TransitionManager.getInstance
member.summary: Singleton's getInstance method.

member.name: M:UsefulThings.WinForms.Transitions.TransitionManager.register(UsefulThings.WinForms.Transitions.Transition)
member.summary: You register a transition with the manager here. This will start to run the transition as the manager's timer ticks.

member.summary: Checks if any existing transitions are acting on the same properties as the transition passed in. If so, we remove the duplicated properties from the older transitions.

member.summary: Finds any properties in the old-transition that are also in the new one, and removes them from the old one.

member.name: T:UsefulThings.WinForms.Transitions.TransitionType_Acceleration
member.summary: Manages transitions under constant acceleration from a standing start.

member.name: M:UsefulThings.WinForms.Transitions.TransitionType_Acceleration.#ctor(System.Int32)
member.summary: Constructor. You pass in the time that the transition will take (in milliseconds).

member.name: M:UsefulThings.WinForms.Transitions.TransitionType_Acceleration.onTimer(System.Int32,System.Double@,System.Boolean@)
member.summary: Works out the percentage completed given the time passed in. This uses the formula: s = ut + 1/2at^2 The initial velocity is 0, and the acceleration to get to 1.0 at t=1.0 is 2, so the formula just becomes: s = t^2

member.name: T:UsefulThings.WinForms.Transitions.TransitionType_Bounce
member.summary: This transition bounces the property to a destination value and back to the original value. It is accelerated to the destination and then decelerated back as if being dropped with gravity and bouncing back against gravity.

member.name: M:UsefulThings.WinForms.Transitions.TransitionType_Bounce.#ctor(System.Int32)
member.summary: Constructor. You pass in the total time taken for the bounce.

member.name: T:UsefulThings.WinForms.Transitions.TransitionType_CriticalDamping
member.summary: This transition animates with an exponential decay. This has a damping effect similar to the motion of a needle on an electomagnetically controlled dial.

member.name: M:UsefulThings.WinForms.Transitions.TransitionType_CriticalDamping.#ctor(System.Int32)
member.summary: Constructor. You pass in the time that the transition will take (in milliseconds).

member.name: T:UsefulThings.WinForms.Transitions.TransitionType_Deceleration
member.summary: Manages a transition starting from a high speed and decelerating to zero by the end of the transition.

member.name: M:UsefulThings.WinForms.Transitions.TransitionType_Deceleration.#ctor(System.Int32)
member.summary: Constructor. You pass in the time that the transition will take (in milliseconds).

member.name: M:UsefulThings.WinForms.Transitions.TransitionType_Deceleration.onTimer(System.Int32,System.Double@,System.Boolean@)
member.summary: Works out the percentage completed given the time passed in. This uses the formula: s = ut + 1/2at^2 The initial velocity is 2, and the acceleration to get to 1.0 at t=1.0 is -2, so the formula becomes: s = t(2-t)

member.name: T:UsefulThings.WinForms.Transitions.TransitionType_EaseInEaseOut
member.summary: Manages an ease-in-ease-out transition. This accelerates during the first half of the transition, and then decelerates during the second half.

member.name: M:UsefulThings.WinForms.Transitions.TransitionType_EaseInEaseOut.#ctor(System.Int32)
member.summary: Constructor. You pass in the time that the transition will take (in milliseconds).

member.name: M:UsefulThings.WinForms.Transitions.TransitionType_EaseInEaseOut.onTimer(System.Int32,System.Double@,System.Boolean@)
member.summary: Works out the percentage completed given the time passed in. This uses the formula: s = ut + 1/2at^2 We accelerate as at the rate needed (a=4) to get to 0.5 at t=0.5, and then decelerate at the same rate to end up at 1.0 at t=1.0.

member.name: T:UsefulThings.WinForms.Transitions.TransitionType_Flash
member.summary: This transition type 'flashes' the properties a specified number of times, ending up by reverting them to their initial values. You specify the number of bounces and the length of each bounce.

member.name: M:UsefulThings.WinForms.Transitions.TransitionType_Flash.#ctor(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: You specify the number of bounces and the time taken for each bounce.

member.name: T:UsefulThings.WinForms.Transitions.TransitionType_Linear
member.summary: This class manages a linear transition. The percentage complete for the transition increases linearly with time.

member.name: M:UsefulThings.WinForms.Transitions.TransitionType_Linear.#ctor(System.Int32)
member.summary: Constructor. You pass in the time (in milliseconds) that the transition will take.

member.name: M:UsefulThings.WinForms.Transitions.TransitionType_Linear.onTimer(System.Int32,System.Double@,System.Boolean@)
member.summary: We return the percentage completed.

member.name: T:UsefulThings.WinForms.Transitions.TransitionType_ThrowAndCatch
member.summary: This transition bounces the property to a destination value and back to the original value. It is decelerated to the destination and then acclerated back as if being thrown against gravity and then descending back with gravity.

member.name: M:UsefulThings.WinForms.Transitions.TransitionType_ThrowAndCatch.#ctor(System.Int32)
member.summary: Constructor. You pass in the total time taken for the bounce.

member.name: T:UsefulThings.WinForms.Transitions.TransitionType_UserDefined
member.summary:
This class allows you to create user-defined transition types. You specify these as a list of TransitionElements. Each of these defines: End time , End value, Interpolation method
For example, say you want to make a bouncing effect with a decay:
EndTime% EndValue% Interpolation -------- --------- ------------- 50 100 Acceleration 75 50 Deceleration 85 100 Acceleration 91 75 Deceleration 95 100 Acceleration 98 90 Deceleration 100 100 Acceleration
The time values are expressed as a percentage of the overall transition time. This means that you can create a user-defined transition-type and then use it for transitions of different lengths.
The values are percentages of the values between the start and end values of the properties being animated in the transitions. 0% is the start value and 100% is the end value.
The interpolation is one of the values from the InterpolationMethod enum.
So the example above accelerates to the destination (as if under gravity) by t=50%, then bounces back up to half the initial height by t=75%, slowing down (as if against gravity) before falling down again and bouncing to decreasing heights each time.

member.name: M:UsefulThings.WinForms.Transitions.TransitionType_UserDefined.#ctor
member.summary: Constructor.

member.name: M:UsefulThings.WinForms.Transitions.TransitionType_UserDefined.#ctor(System.Collections.Generic.IList{UsefulThings.WinForms.Transitions.TransitionElement},System.Int32)
member.summary: Constructor. You pass in the list of TransitionElements and the total time (in milliseconds) for the transition.

member.summary: Sets up the transitions.

member.name: M:UsefulThings.WinForms.Transitions.Utility.raiseEvent``1(System.EventHandler{``0},System.Object,``0)
member.summary: Fires the event passed in in a thread-safe way.
member.remarks: This method loops through the targets of the event and invokes each in turn. If the target supports ISychronizeInvoke (such as forms or controls) and is set to run on a different thread, then we call BeginInvoke to marshal the event to the target thread. If the target does not support this interface (such as most non-form classes) or we are on the same thread as the target, then the event is fired on the same thread as this is called from.

member.name: T:UsefulThings.WrappingCollection`1
member.summary: This Collection wraps its index such that if length = 2, and the call is list[6], the collection would return the first element. Negative indicies are also supported (maybe)

member.summary: Number of elements in collection.

member.summary: This is always false.

member.summary: Creates a collection whose index wraps back to the start when exceeded.
